\chapter{ForwardKinematics module}
\label{\detokenize{ForwardKinematics:module-Forward_Kinematics}}\label{\detokenize{ForwardKinematics:forwardkinematics-module}}\label{\detokenize{ForwardKinematics:welcome-to-matrices-manipulation-s-documentation}}\label{\detokenize{ForwardKinematics::doc}}\index{Forward\_Kinematics (module)}\index{ForwardKinematics (class in Forward\_Kinematics)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ForwardKinematics:Forward_Kinematics.ForwardKinematics}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Forward\_Kinematics.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{ForwardKinematics}}}{\emph{**kwargs}}{}
Bases: \sphinxhref{https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html\#object}{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}}

Definition: This class generates Homogeneous transform matrices, although it uses a symbolic approach
that can be used to multiply any matrix and obtain the translation or rotation.

sympy.cos and sympy.sin: cos and sin for sympy

sympy.simplify: SymPy has dozens of functions to perform various kinds of simplification.
simplify() attempts to apply all of these functions
in an intelligent way to arrive at the simplest form of an expression.

Returns: It returns Rotation and translation matrices.

Obs: {\color{red}\bfseries{}**}kwargs (keyword arguments) are used to facilitate the identification of the parameters, so initiate the
object
\index{rot\_x() (Forward\_Kinematics.ForwardKinematics method)}

        \PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        Definition: Translates the matrix a given amount {}`a{}` on the *X* axis by Defining a 4x4 identity}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        matrix with {}`a{}` as the (1,4) element.}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{        :type a: string}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        :param a: Distance translated on the X\PYGZhy{}axis}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{        Returns: The Translation Matrix on the *X* axis by a given distance}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}

    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{rot\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{rot\PYGZus{}z}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{theta}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        Definition: Receives an theta angle and returns the rotation matrix for the given angle at the *Z* axis.}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{        :type theta: string}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        :param theta: Rotation Angle around the Z axis}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{        Returns: The Rotational Matrix at the Z axis by an *given* angle}

\section{Running the documentation with Sphinx}
\label{\detokenize{index:running-the-documentation-with-sphinx}}
To run the documentation for this project run the following commands, at the project folder:
\begin{quote}

Install Spinxs:

\sphinxstylestrong{python -m pip install sphinx}

Install the “Read the Docs” theme:

\sphinxstylestrong{pip install sphinx-rtd-theme}

\sphinxstylestrong{make clean}

\sphinxstylestrong{make html}
\end{quote}


\section{GitHub Repository}
\label{\detokenize{index:github-repository}}
Find all the files at the GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/ThiagoSoutoGit/OpenCVMatrices}{here}.
